Settle Now (true/false)

Notes: Configuration typically requires two steps: 1. Test with Test URL, 2. Test with Production URL.

article.title: LinkPoint API
article.story:
Information Needed For LinkPoint API Configuration

Required Information:Store ID#
PEM File
CC Processor:LinkPoint2
MerchantAccountNumber: [Store ID#] | [ClientFolder] \ [Name of LinkPoint Folder] \ [PEM File Name]
Example: 1001310107|TroopTickets\LinkPoint\1001310107.pem
Script: /LinkPoint2.asp
Notes: The client should be able to generate their PEM file by following these steps:
1. Login to their LinkPoint account. Enter the login ID and the password assigned by LinkPoint/YourPay.
2. Download PEM (encryption) File. On the top/left navigation, click on Support and then Download Center. ON the main part of the page, underneath "Store Cert File" click on â€œDownload Nowâ€ in the middle of the page. It will request Tax ID Number. Enter the Tax ID or Social Security Number, without dashes or spaces. Click on â€œAPI Downloadâ€. The browser will ask to open or save the file. Save the file to a location on the computer that can easily be found. The file name will be the Store ID number with an extension of â€œpemâ€. E-mail the file to us. Store ID is usually a number beginning with â€œ10â€.Once that is done, we need to do the following:
1. Save the file to the clientâ€™s directory in a subdirectory called â€œLinkPointâ€.
2. Upload the new directory and file to the LinkPoint web server (72.3.138.32), and not web12 or web13.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: gateway,merchant account,ecommerce,credit card

article.title: ACCESSIBLE SEATING
article.story: Locations reserved for individuals who are in a wheelchair or are physically unable to get to the general public area. Most facilities will block a number of seats for this purpose, whether in a designated section or in individual accessible rows.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ACCESSIBLE TICKETS
article.story: Tickets issued to certain areas that can accommodate accessible seating requests (i.e. hearing impaired, visually impaired, physically impaired).
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ADVANCE SALES
article.story: Tickets that are sold prior to the walkup of an event. This includes customers who do not walk immediately into the event after purchasing their tickets.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ADVANCE SALES WINDOW
article.story: Selling window where customers can purchase tickets for future events.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: AMEX
article.story: American Express card method of payment
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ARTIST HOLDS
article.story: Tickets being held away from public sale for use by the artist.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ASSISTANT BOX OFFICE MANAGER
article.story: Individual who assists in the management of box office operations.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: AUDIT REPORT
article.story: A computer generated report listing capacities, holds and accumulated ticket sales by price.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BAGGED
article.story: Process by which the deposit is prepared for pickup.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BANK FEE
article.story: Fee charged for Banking Services.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BLOCK OF SEATS
article.story: A group of tickets located in a specific seating area.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BOX OFFICE CASH REQUEST FORM
article.story: Form sent to Finance department requesting a specific dollar amount of cash from the bank for a specified reason.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BOX OFFICE MANAGER
article.story: Individual who manages and is ultimately responsible for effective operation of the box office.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BOX OFFICE STAFF
article.story: A staff consisting of managers, supervisors and ticket sellers. This elite staff is responsible for advance and day of tickets sales for all events.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BOX OFFICE STATEMENT
article.story: This is the final statement that is produced by the Box Office to show final ticket sales. It states the capacity of the venue by ticket price, al unsold tickets, complimentary tickets, discounted tickets and full price sold tickets. In addition to the ticket numbers, it reflects the corresponding dollar value, which is the gross ticket sales for a show. From this figure, a building settlement package is derived.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BULLET PROOF RESISTANT GLASS
article.story: The clear glass in front of the ticket seller that has been proven to be unbreakable and to resist bullets. A Box Office may or may not contain this as a safety precaution.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CASH ADVANCE
article.story: Request to Finance for payouts for services on the night of event, as requested by promoter. Can also be an advance on ticket sales to promoter.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CASH CARD
article.story: Report printed on ticket stock that represents sellers total sales on computer ticket system.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CASH DRAWER
article.story: A drawer with money dividers for the purpose of keeping currency and coin safely while selling tickets. This drawer will include a pre-determined amount of start-up bank given to the seller by the Box Office Manager.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CASH PICK-UP
article.story: Procedure in which a security company representative takes possession of the box office daily deposits and delivers it to the bank.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CHANGE FUND
article.story: Extra monies kept on hand to make change, both internally to sellers, and externally with bank. Part of box office bank.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CHARGE AUTHORIZATION MACHINE
article.story: A machine that can run on a point of sale authorization system, in which after a sale is performed, the seller will obtain an authorization number verifying funds for the transaction. Afterwards, an imprint of the card is usually required for customer signature.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CHARGE SLIPS
article.story: Actual form slip that a customer has signed, when tickets are purchased with a credit card. This slip is retained for accounting purposes.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: COMP
article.story: Any ticket that has been issued free of charge by the building General Manager or show Promoter is referred to as having been comped.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: COMPLIMENTARY TICKET FORM
article.story: A form, in triplicate, showing specific seat and row location for complimentary tickets. This must be signed by the person picking up the tickets.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: COMPLIMENTARY TICKET LOG
article.story: A list of Complimentary Ticket forms issued for a single event.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CONSIGNED TICKETS
article.story: Tickets given to a consignee without full payment; payment arrangements are made between consignor and consignee.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CONSIGNEE
article.story: An entity that receives tickets without full payment.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CONSIGNMENT LOG
article.story: Journal tracking and balance of consigned tickets and their subsequent payment by cash or ticket return. Journal should list consignee names, number of tickets, seat locations, and ticket values.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: COUNTING ROOM
article.story: A designated area or room in which a vault is usually kept, and monies are counted and bundled for deposit.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CREDIT CARD DRAFTS
article.story: Cash advances provided for a customer by charging a like amount against the customers credit card.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DEPOSIT
article.story: Sum of cash and checks to be put into a bank account.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DEPOSIT SLIP
article.story: A form issued by the bank to record currency, coin and check deposits.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DIRECTOR OF FINANCE
article.story: A person who reports to the General Manager and is in charge of the Box Office operation as well as the entire financial operation of the facility.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DIRECTOR OF SECURITY
article.story: A person who reports to the General Manager and is responsible for the security of the facility, as well as general operation of that facility.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DISCOUNT COUPONS
article.story: These are coupons used by the promoter and/or the marketing department to promote ticket sales. When use, the indicated discount value is deducted from the full price of a ticket to encourage patrons to purchase tickets.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DISCOUNT PRICE KEY
article.story: The computerized ticketing system is capable of pulling tickets off at discounted prices. This is performed by assigning a specified price to a certain key on the keyboard. When a discount key is used during purchasing of a ticket, the corresponding price will be reflected on the ticket and in the system.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DOG
article.story: When a show goes on sale and is not selling well, it is referred by this term.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DRAWER
article.story: See CASH DRAWER
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DRESS CODE
article.story: Neat and professional looking attire.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EMPLOYEE TICKET REQUEST FORM
article.story: Form employees must complete to request house seating. Form includes name of person, name of event and its day, date, time and method of payment and total due.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EXCHANGE FEE
article.story: Fee charged when a customer wishes to exchange tickets.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EXECUTIVE OFFICES
article.story: Offices for personnel directly involved in the management of the facility.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EXECUTIVE SALES REPORT
article.story: A daily summary analysis of Box Office and Remotes transactions reflecting all events currently on sale at that facility.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: GENERAL MANAGER
article.story: A person that is responsible for the entire operation of the facility.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: GROUP SALES
article.story: The department in charge of sales of blocks of tickets for groups of individuals (such as schools, churches, and elderly communities), for an event. This department can also handle discounts for a particular association and/or group.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: HOLDS
article.story: An area of seating not available to the general public.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: HOUSE SEATS
article.story: Preferred seating reserved and used at the discretion of building management.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: INFORMATION WINDOW
article.story: Non-selling window where customers can obtain information regarding upcoming events, group sales, season tickets, handicapped seating, locations of first-aid, restrooms, security, eating facilities. May also handle complaints.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: INTERCOM SYSTEM
article.story: An intercom is a wired voice system that allows two or more people to talk to each other from different areas.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: INTERNAL AUDIT DEPARTMENT
article.story: Checks to accuracy of all Box Office receipts; reviews financial controls within the Box office.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: KILLS
article.story: A term referred to seats that are not sold due to a number of factors, with the most important being sight-line obstructions and non-saleable riser and mixer positioned seats.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MANIFESTS
article.story: A written, sometimes bonded or notarized, list of enclosure. Used in box office to state hard or roll tickets printed by ticket company, as in number, color, price, type, etc.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MC/VISA
article.story: Mastercard/VISA are two types of credit cards used as a method of payment.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MESSAGE BOARD
article.story: A place near the box office windows where information pertaining to events is displayed.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MOBILITY IMPAIRED BOX OFFICE WINDOWS
article.story: A box office window designed to facilitate the sale of tickets to disabled customers. These windows must be easily accessible to individuals who are confined to wheelchairs. An open exit way is very important.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MOTION DETECTORS
article.story: This is part of the security system in an office setting. When the system is activated, any movement detected in its aim will sound an alarm to warn of an intruder.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MIXER KILLS
article.story: An area of seating unsold due to anticipation of a sound mixer being in that location.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MULTIPLE EVENT DAYS
article.story: Days on which there are more than one show or event occurring at the same venue.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MULTIPLE RUN SHOWS
article.story: Events that have more than one show a day or several days of consecutive shows at the same venue (i.e. family shows).
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: N.S.F. CHECKS
article.story: Checks deposited and returned from the bank for "Non-Sufficient Funds", meaning not enough funds in account to cover check. Service charge from the bank to the merchant is often passed along to the customer who must reimburse the merchant, usually with cash or money order.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: NON-CASH CONSIGNMENT VALUE
article.story: The dollar value of tickets given to a consignee.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: NOVELTY ITEMS
article.story: Tangible gods that are sold that have to do with the event in the building. Examples are concert t-shirts, programs, wrestling paraphernalia, balloons, etc.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: OPEN
article.story: This is the terminology for tickets on the Ticketmaster system that area available to the public for sale.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: OUTSTANDING CONSIGNMENT
article.story: Tickets that are given on consignment to various satellite offices that have not been returned by the scheduled deadline.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: OVERAGES AND SHORTAGES LOG
article.story: Log kept on a daily basis recording, by seller, overages and shortages. May track patterns.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PANIC BUTTON
article.story: Indicator buttons are placed in a hidden location at all ticket windows. When pressed, they sound an alarm at a remote location, indicating a problem.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PAPER THE HOUSE
article.story: Refers to the practice followed when a show has not sold too well and you want the house to look full when the performance takes place. This is done in many ways. You may issue complimentary tickets to civic groups or needy organizations or you can offer extreme discounts to those aforementioned groups with the goal in mind to fill the empty seats. What you lose in ticket revenues you may be able to help offset by selling concessions and novelties.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PASS RETURNS/REFUNDS
article.story: Tickets that are returned to the computer ticket system on a day other than the day they were pulled.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PATRONAGE
article.story: The support and/or influence of a patron.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PATRONS
article.story: Individuals attending an event held at a venue.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PEEP HOLES
article.story: Device mounted in a door that will allow you to identify an individual to determine if he/she has the authority to enter the Box Office area before opening the door.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PHONE ORDERS
article.story: Tickets sold via telephone. The customer normally calls a telephone line specifically set up for the taking of phone orders. The customer pays for the tickets by providing a charge card number. The tickets are then mailed or left in will call for the customer to pick up.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PHONE ORDER LIST
article.story: A list of names and addresses of people who placed telephone orders for future use.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: POLICE REPORT
article.story: An official document describing incidents or events that have occurred. For example: In the case of stolen tickets reported, a police report must show the number of tickets and for which event they were purchased, also seat location, if possible. This is needed in order to issue a relocation slip.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PRE-PULLED TICKETS
article.story: Tickets pulled from a computer ticket system and sold as hard tickets. Usually done before events with extremely large walk-up expected. Tickets are pre-pulled to expedite selling process.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PRODUCTION KILLS
article.story: Unsold seats not included in capacity due to use for technical equipment.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PROGRAMMING EVENT
article.story: Term used in computerized ticketing. Necessary information as to day, date, time, prices, discounts, ticket copy, on sale time, ticket limit, configuration, scaling, holds, handicapped seating, etc. Generally, box office feeds computerized ticket company information to program the event, then checks accuracy and correctness
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PROMOTER
article.story: An individual who contracts an artist or event to be performed at a facility. One who takes the responsibility of booking the facility and handling all the financial matters pertaining to gross receipts of an event
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REBATE
article.story: A return of a part of either ticket price or service charge
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RECORD LABELS
article.story: The music company that the groups/acts albums/music are distributed under
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REFUNDS
article.story: Monies returned to customers for postponed or canceled events
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REFUND JOURNAL
article.story: A ticketing system generated report listing all tickets returned to the system during a specified time period. The journal should include seller code, event, seat location, time of transaction, and dollar value of returned tickets
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REKEYED
article.story: This is the terminology for changing the tumblers in a door's locking system that will require a new key. This is usually done when an employee who has a key leaves to be assured for proper security
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RELOCATION
article.story: A replacement seat or group of seats issued to accommodate a patron with one of many possible problems. Problems may range from bad viewing to dirty to non-existent seating
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RELOCATION PASS
article.story: A substitute for an original ticket; a form in triplicate issued to patrons for the reassignment of seat location due to lost tickets or obstructed view, etc
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RELOCATION SLIP
article.story: See RELOCATION PASS
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RELOCATION PERSON
article.story: A person solely in charge of handling the relocation of a person(s) to seats other than the ones they had originally purchased, due to either problems with those seats or problems with the person(s) that bought those seats
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REMOTES
article.story: Often referred to as "outlets." Locations provided for ticket sales other than the main box office. Remotes make it more convenient for the customer, while at the same time, increasing sales for the event
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REOPEN
article.story: This command is used to re-enter a ticket or number of tickets back onto the Ticketmaster system after they have been pulled off. This command has checks built into it to assure the proper tickets are put back into the system
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RESERVATION ( Will Call) WINDOWS
article.story: The window in the box office dedicated to orders that have been called in advance that need to be picked up which sometimes are prepaid and sometimes not. The same goes for complimentary tickets from the building or promoter
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RESERVED GROUPS
article.story: Sections and blocks of seats held for group sales.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ROLLED TICKETS
article.story: Non-computerized tickets; a continuous strip of generically numbered tickets with perforations between each ticket.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ROLLED TICKET NUMBER
article.story: The number on a strip style tickets. The number is usually located on the end of the ticket itself. (The number on a raffle ticket)
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ROLLED TICKET CUMULATIVE BOX OFFICE REPORT
article.story: Information taken from roll ticket settlement form to be used on Box Office settlement; showing number of tickets sold at each price with total gross receipts.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SAFE
article.story: A place that is secure with a combination and key to store all monies that pertain to the box office sales and operations, to safeguard against unauthorized access.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SATELLITE BOX OFFICE
article.story: Portable ticket booths set apart from the main box office. Satellite box offices are used mainly for day of event ticket sales, when walk-up is too heavy for the main box office windows to handle. Satellite box offices are also used to alleviate congestion in any given area.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEALED
article.story: Term meaning the deposit bag has been closed with either a lead bag seal or self adhesive tape.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEASON TICKET HOLDERS
article.story: Individuals who contracted and paid for a seat for the season of multiple date events.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEATING CAPACITY
article.story: The total number of seats that can be set up for an event.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEATING CHART
article.story: A diagram of the seating and physical set-up of an event used by ticket sellers to explain to customers the location of tickets that they are purchasing.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SELLER CODE
article.story: Code which represents seller's identity on computer ticket system.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SELLER MACHINE SETTLEMENT
article.story: Verifies all daily transactions made by each seller; determines the amount of income for each seller.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SELLER ROLLED TICKET SETTLEMENT
article.story: Verifies starting and ending numbers on ticket rolls given to individual ticket sellers.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SELLER'S SHEET
article.story: Also known as a Cashier's Settlement Sheet, the Seller's Sheet is a reconciliation for an individual cashier's transactions during their shift of work. It is completed at the end of their shift. This includes their cash, checks, credit cards, consignments, gift certificates, and returned tickets collected for the return or sale of "hard" and computerized tickets.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SERVICE CHARGE
article.story: Additional charge added to mail or phone orders for tickets.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SETTLEMENT
article.story: Procedure used to settle financial end of event between Promoter and Venue as event transpires. Various departments submit costs, bills, services, and revenues. Box office submits box office statement, pass list, paid outs, cash advances, as required.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SETTLEMENT PACKAGE
article.story: This is the final package put together to settle a show. In addition to the final Box Office statement, it contains all related show costs broken down by department. It also contains all advances in the terms of money that were received by the act or promoter. The package also reflects receivables to settle the show such as allotted tickets that must be settled on
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BOX OFFICE SETTLEMENT PACKAGE
article.story: All final documentation pertaining to gross sales receipts, e.g.. Box Office Statement, audit, discount coupons, group sales forms, complimentary ticket forms
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SHOW FILE
article.story: A file kept by the Box Office containing all pertinent information regarding a specific event, (beginning audit, maps, comp list, consignment forms, Box Office Report and backup.)
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SHOW TIME
article.story: The time that an event is scheduled to begin. May also refer to when a scheduled event actually begins
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SIGNAGE
article.story: Advertising space usually sold on a rental basis to those who wish to advertise within the facility
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SOLD OUT
article.story: When there are no tickets available for sale to the public
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SPEAKER HOLE
article.story: The hole in the ticket seller's window that will enable to customer both to speak to and hear the seller
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: STUBBING THE TICKET
article.story: When working with hard tickets, or tickets that are pulled off at full price, discounting a ticket is tracked by stubbing one part of the ticket. Usually a ticket has two perforations. One of these perforated segments would be torn off as the stubbed section of the ticket. This stub is retained and its discounted value is taken into account in settling the seller and the show
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TAG (FOR CASH BAG)
article.story: Tag that denotes the dollar amount enclosed in the cash bag deposit and the account number in which it should be deposited
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET COMPANY
article.story: Company that supplies tickets. Can be computerized or hard tickets. Provides physical method of incoming revenue for ticketed events
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET ENVELOPES
article.story: A small envelope to place tickets in after a customer has purchased them. This envelope could carry advertisement from a sponsor or the Center itself
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: COMPUTERIZED TICKETING EQUIPMENT
article.story: This is a machine designed to print tickets for all events. The system consists of a CRT screen, keyboard and a ticket printer
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET MACHINE
article.story: A system consisting of CRT and a ticket printer. This machine is hooked up to a computerized ticketing system. (Ticketmaster, Tickets.com). This system will enable the seller to print specified seats within a section, row, etc
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET SELLERS
article.story: Persons that sell tickets to events at the facility, authorized to handle cash and transactions, relating to sales
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET STOCK
article.story: A block of blank tickets that is used in a computer printer, which should be stored in a secure place.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET TEXT OR HEADER
article.story: The area of a ticket reserved for event information such as name, headliner, and venue and sometimes date
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TIME SHEETS
article.story: Formatted method of tracking payroll for individuals employed. Submitted on regular, established basis, often weekly or bi-weekly. Includes name, hours worked, rate of pay
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TODAY'S RETURNS
article.story: Tickets pulled off ticket system, inadvertently, and are returned the same business day
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TOUR ACCOUNTANT
article.story: The person traveling with the performer and who may be present at settlement time. This individual may request audits, maps, etc. for said event, and is considered the liaison between the promoter and the artist
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: VAULT COMBINATION
article.story: This is a present series of numbers that when turned to on a vault dial, will open the vault door
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: VAULT LOG
article.story: A recording of all cash advances and withdrawals from the box office safe
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: VAULT RECONCILIATION
article.story: The monitoring and verification of a predetermined balance in the vault
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: VENUE
article.story: The place in which events are held
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: WILL CALL
article.story: Orders that are held at the box office for customer pickup (tickets and/or C.O. D. on delivery)
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: WILL CALL WINDOWS
article.story: Similar in scope to the reservation windows but which are mainly used for pick-up of pre-ordered phone charge tickets. A specific or clearly marked window in the box office where only customers picking up prepaid and C.O.D. tickets are waited on
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: WINDOW NUMBER
article.story: If your box office has more than one window, you would number them for the ease of directing someone to the right window
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: WALK-UP
article.story: The term given to sales that are made the same day of the show, of tickets that are purchased at the box office only
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BOX OFFICE WINDOW/TICKET SELLER WINDOW
article.story: Area separating a customer from a Box Office employee, and is accessible to servicing that customer. This is where an individual is stationed to greet and assist customers
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: WIRE TRANSFER
article.story: Direct electronic transfer of funds from one bank account to another. Can be used as method of payment at settlement, payment to or by a Ticket Company, cash advance, or internal transfer of funds
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: WRIST BANDS
article.story: Weatherproof bracelets used by a venue or promoter to denote special privileges, backstage access, alcohol check and line up positions
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ZERO VALUE
article.story: A ticket with no dollar value showing on the face of the ticket, such as a complimentary ticket. This ticket cannot be sold for a dollar amount
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: AISLE SEAT
article.story: A seat with only one adjacent seat. Aisle seats include seats that are at the opposite ends of a row and seats in the middle of a row represented by signs on the computer screen
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: BACKSPACE KEY
article.story: Used to back the cursor up one space at a time to delete characters
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CAPS LOCK KEY
article.story: Locks the keyboard so that only capital letters are typed. This must be on at all times
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CARRIAGE RETURN
article.story: Another name for the [Enter] key. See Enter
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CHECK NUMBER
article.story: A number that appears on the face of every sold ticket. It is used in tracking tickets and is necessary in refunding tickets
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: LOGGING IN
article.story: Used to gain access to the Tix system. At the start of your shift, you must log into the TIX system by entering your user id and password
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: LOGGING OUT
article.story: Exiting the Tix system
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: COMPUTERIZED TICKETING
article.story: Selling tickets through a computer system. The customers will have access to the best available seats whether they purchase their tickets through the box office, a ticket center or telephone sales center
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CONVENIENCE FEE
article.story: Another term for Service Charge. See Service Charge
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: CURRENT EVENT (CURRENT EVENT CODE)
article.story: This event is the current event until another event code is entered
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DATA
article.story: Information that is electronically transmitted to and received from the computer
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DATE FORMAT
article.story: The format that Ticketmaster system requires for specifying dates: dd-mm-yy
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DELETE KEY
article.story: Deletes characters one at a time on the line you are currently entering. Will start with the character immediately to the right of the cursor and deletes each character after it, one at a time for each time the delete key is depressed
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DEMO EVENT CODE
article.story: A made-up event specifically created for training purposes. Demo operator codes have access to demo event codes
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: DEMO OPERATOR CODE
article.story: An operator code specifically designed for training purposes. A demo operator code must be used when practicing on the system. This will alleviate the danger of inadvertently changing data for a real event
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ENTER
article.story: To enter a command (e.g. letter, number or symbol), by typing the characters and then pressing the [ENTER] key, which on some keyboards may be called "Return."
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EVENT
article.story: Represented by an event code on the Ticketmaster system. Examples of Ticketmaster events are rock concerts, operas, dances, sporting events, cruises, etc
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EVENT CALENDAR
article.story: A chronological listing of events currently available on the TM system
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EVENT CODES
article.story: Represents an event or a series of events on the Ticketmaster system. Event codes always start with the letter "E." They can consist of up to eight alphanumeric characters
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EVENT INFORMATION
article.story: Any information that is unique to an event: performance, show times, ticket prices, ticket types, etc
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EVENT NAME
article.story: Event names are used in finding events on the system. They may be complete names, e.g., The Rolling Stones or abbreviated, e.g., Stones
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: EVENT PERFORMANCE DATE
article.story: The date when the event is taking place. Sometimes referred to as "EP date"
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: FACILITY
article.story: The location where an event takes place such as arena, stadium or theater
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: FACILITY INFORMATION
article.story: Any information that pertains to a specific facility. This information may be associated with any event being held at that facility
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: GENERAL ADMISSION EVENT
article.story: An event without pre-assigned seating. Customers take their seats on a first-come, first-served basis
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: INFORMATION or EXTENDED COMMENT LINE
article.story: A brief line of information about a specific event. Information lines appear on the screen when listing event calendars, selling tickets and refunding tickets
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: KEYBOARD
article.story: Used to enter and send information to the Ticketmaster computer
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MAIL
article.story: Electronically transmitted information sent either to just one operator code (personal mail) or to all the sellers (broadcast mail)
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MAP
article.story: A display of a facility's seating arrangement on the computer screen. Also another name for a Seating Chart
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MAP BOOK
article.story: A collection of seating charts for all the facilities using Ticketmaster services. Each Ticketmaster system has a separate Map Book. Refer to this map book to show the customers where their seats are located
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MAP NAME
article.story: A page number in your map book where you will find a seating chart for the current event. The map number appears on the information line
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MONITOR (SCREEN OR CRT)
article.story: The area where information sent from the TM computer to your location will be displayed
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: MULTI-USER SYSTEM
article.story: A system that is accessible by many users.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: NON-EXISTENT SEATS
article.story: These seats are indicated by dashes and cannot be sold
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: NUMERIC KEY PAD
article.story: A small block of keys on the right hand side of the keyboard, used to type in numbers
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: OPEN SEATS
article.story: Number of seats available for sale. Although this information is available to you, you may not quote it to customers
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: USER ID
article.story: A code assigned specifically to one seller to prevent fraud and entry by unauthorized users
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PASSWORD
article.story: A preventive measure to prevent entry onto the system by unauthorized users. Comprised of 1-8 characters selected by the user
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: PRICE LEVEL
article.story: Determines a ticket's price. Facility seating is usually separated into several price levels. As the price level increases, the ticket price decreases. The highest priced tickets will have a price level of one
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: QUICK SELL
article.story: A selling method used for major on-sales. The transaction is assumed to be for cash and there is no option given to cancel the order
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REFUNDS EXCHANGE FEE
article.story: The fee that the customer paid as a convenience charge when he/she purchased the tickets. The convenience fee generally is not refundable
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REPRINTABLE
article.story: A seat that is in hold status as a result of an interruption in the printing process (a void ticket may have been issued). This seat may be reprinted (not through the SELL command) and sold by contacting your local Ticketmaster office or box-office supervisor
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: REPRINTED TICKET
article.story: A reprintable ticket that was printed and sold
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RESERVED SEATING EVENTS
article.story: An event with specific seat assignments. A ticket for a reserved seating event will have a specific section name, row and seat number
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: RETURN
article.story: See Enter
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: ROW
article.story: Represents vertical positioning of a seat within a section. Every seat in a section has a horizontal position (seat number) and a vertical position (row number or name)
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEATING CHART
article.story: A representation of the seating arrangement within a facility. You use a seating chart to show customers where their seats are located.
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEAT NUMBERS
article.story: Horizontal positioning of a seat within a section. See Row
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SEAT STATUS
article.story: The classification of a seat. Examples are: SOLD, OPEN, HOLD, etc
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SECTION NAME
article.story: The description given to a block of seats that comprise a familiar area of a facility
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SECTION
article.story: A specific seating area within a facility. The section name is printed on the ticket and is used to find the location of the seats within the facility
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SERVICE CHARGE
article.story: A fee charged by Ticketmaster on every ticket sold through the TM Telephone Center or a TM Ticket Center. This fee is usually non-refundable
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SHOW TIME
article.story: A time when the event (performance) starts
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: SYSTEM
article.story: A combination of computer hardware and software. In this manual, system, computer system, TM system and TM computer are used interchangeably
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET LIMIT
article.story: Maximum number of tickets a customer may purchase from a Ticketmaster Ticket Center. The ticket limit may not be exceeded without prior authorization from Ticketmaster
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET ORDER
article.story: The first letter of a ticket type followed by the number of tickets desired. If the number of tickets is not specified, the computer assumes it is 1. If multiple ticket types are required, you may enter the orders on the same line
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET PRICE
article.story: Refers to the price for one ticket for a particular event
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: TICKET PRINTER
article.story: A high-speed machine solely designed to print computerized tickets
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez
article.tags: glossary, box office basics, jargon, training, word meaning

article.title: Discount Management and Limiting Discounts per Customer
article.story:
Â 

Â 

Â 

From: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Joe Iacoponi
Sent: Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Tuesday, October 30, 2012 3:45 PM
To: Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  robert.edmison@tix.com; 'Silvia Mahoney'; Steve Moore; adam.hettinger@tix.com; sergio.rodriguez@tix.com; Luke Perea;
Subject: Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Discount Management and Limiting Discounts per Customer

Â 

Hi all,

Â 

We have now added a new capability into all of the generic discounts that will allow us to limit discounts by customer and by customer/event.

Â 

Please Note: Â This new restriction will currently only work for Tix 2 clients, and only for Internet sales.

Â 

The Tix system will bypass this restriction, and the discount will be applied, if the customer number on the order is Guest Shopper (1).Â 

Â This means that for Tix 1 and Management orders, this discount restriction will not work unless a customer is first attached to the order and then they go back to the Shopping Cart.

Â 

The new settings are as follows, and need to be entered into the Additional Parameters field within Discount Management:

Â 

&MaxDiscountsPerCustomer=XÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (Limits the discount across all orders/events for that same customer)

&MaxDiscountsPerCustomerPerEvent=XÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (Limits the discount across all orders for that same customer and event)

Â 

with X equal to the maximum number of discounts allowed.

Â 

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Â 

Joe Iacoponi
http://www.tix.com
(800) 504-4849 x211 (toll-free)
(562) 285-4212 (fax)
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez

article.title: Customer Lookup Change
article.story:
From: Robert Edmison

Sent: Friday, January 07, 2011 11:31 AM

To: 'Joe Iacoponi'; 'Luke Perea'; Patti.Sutlick@TIX.com; 'Ron Stern'; 'Sergio Rodriguez'; 'Silvia Mahoney'; 'Steve Moore'

Subject: Customer Lookup Change

I just made a change to the Customer Lookup function within Management ticket sales. The following has been added to Tix News:

Customer Lookup Change - The Customer Lookup function when performing phone, fax, mail, box office, and comp ticket orders has been modified. We've moved the email address lookup to the top lookup method above the phone number lookup. We are also now displaying the email address in the search result listing. These changes are a result of a recent change to prevent duplicate email addresses from being entered into the system.

If you have any questions about this update, please give us a call at (800) 504-4849, Extension 3 (Technical Support).

Please let me know if you have any questions or issues.

Thanks,

Robert
article.author: Sergio Rodriguez

article.title: Thermal Printer Installation
article.story:
The following guide will walk you through the necessary steps to successfully install and configure your printer. If you are new to thermal printing, please review the ‘How does thermal printing work?‘ section of the feature page and read our three part whitepaper!

Thermal Printer Installation

1. Download Printer Drivers from Manufacturers web site, or http://bocasystems.com/driver.php

2. Follow the Add Printers wizard for proper printer installation

3. Print a test page

  • Right click on Boca printer and select Printer Properties
  • Click on the General Tab
  • Click on the Print Test Page

4. If your printer successfully prints a test page, it has been installed properly

5. Right click on your printer, and select Set as Default Printer

Printer Settings

In order for your printer to print tickets properly, you will need to make the following modifications.

1. Right click on your Boca printer and select Printer Preferences

2. Select the Layout tab

  • Under the Orientation pull down menu, select Landscape
  • Under the Page Order pull down menu, select Back to Front
  • Click on the Advanced button
  • Under the Paper Size pull down menu, select Concert Size

Internet Explorer Settings

Internet Explorer offers the best printing reliability and compatibility with our thermal printing module. For accurate printing results, do not login to the system using any other internet browser.

1. Launch Internet Explorer

2. Click on File and select Page Setup

3. Under Paper Options, set Page Size to USER, and the page orientation should be set to Landscape

4. Margin settings:

  • Left: 0.01
  • Right: 0
  • Top: 0.01
  • Bottom: 0

5. Select the Shrink-to-Fit Option

6. Under Headers and Footers

  • Set all Header options to Empty
  • Set all Footer options to Empty
  • Click on the OK button

IMPORTANT NOTE:
Internet Explorer does not allow you to set the Boca printer’s left and right margins to 0, and they will default to 0.01. You will have to manually set these margins to 0 by editing the registry.

Registry Changes

Improperly modifying the registry can result in adverse effects to your system. We recommend that you have someone with a technical background help you with these modifications and that a registry backup is made prior to making any changes.

1. Run registry editor command: regedit

  • Click on the HKEY_CURRENT_USER folder
  • Click on the Software folder
  • Click on the Microsoft folder

2. Under the Internet Explorer folder, click on the PageSetup sub-folder

  • Double click on the margin_bottom registry entry and set the value to 0
  • Double click on the margin_left registry entry and set the value to 0
  • Double click on the margin_right registry entry and set the value to 0
  • Double click on the margin_top registry entry and set the value to 0

3. Click OK

IMPORTANT NOTE:
Any modification made to the browser’s Page Setup section will result in having to reset the margin_bottom, margin_left, margin_right, and margin_top registry values to 0 in the registry. Tickets will not properly print if the registry settings are not set back to 0.
